brewery.brewery_description: Sambrook's have been brewing quality cask (real ale), bottle and keg craft beer at our brewery in Battersea, London, since 2008. We use traditional brewing techniques alongside carefully selected ingredients, which our brewers use to create exceptionally tasting beers.

venue.venue_name: Tower Bridge Arms: A BrewDog Pub
Tower Bridge Arms: A BrewDog Pub

items.badge_description: There's beer in them thar hills! You're setting off on your journey through the world of beer, but be sure to take a little time to get to know each brewery as you go. That's a beer from 375 different breweries. Try 5 more for Level 76!
Keep the party rolling all day long with your favorite low ABV session IPAs. That's 35 different beers with style of IPA - Session. Try 5 more for Level 8!

beer.beer_description:
Our pale ale was christened by a local drinker, naming it after the iconic Battersea Park Pumphouse. Packed full of hops, our pale ale is a nod to overseas pale ale styles but keeps true to our British roots.
INGREDIENTS:
Maris Otter Pale Malt, Admiral, First Gold, Celeia and New Zealand Hallertau Hops.

items.badge_description: Had enough tea and biscuits? Head to the pub for a pint! That's at least 10 beers from the UK. Try 5 more for Level 3.

items.checkin_comment: this was so much nicer than the first beer we had i'm actually quite sad to give it a 3 but in fairness to myself its my 2nd check in and i had in total honesty cried before i drank this x

user.bio:
loves a beer and also to have fun!
will also write an essay about every beer i try because everything means a lot to me

beer.beer_description:
What better way to launch the first beer in our seasonal range that by brewing a porter; a style of beer synonymous with London. We looked no further for inspiration than Battersea‚Äôs most famous landmark (the Power Station) in naming our porter ‚Äì a strong rich beer needs a strong name. 

I personally love porters ‚Äì the richness and complexity from the different malts, the roasted coffee aroma and that feeling of pure satisfaction when supping one by a warm log fire. If you like porters I am sure that you won‚Äôt be disappointed by our modern take on this classic London beer style. If you have yet to try a porter....well what are you waiting for?.

user.bio:
Life Is Too Short To Drink Crap Beer

Brewing Operative @ Greene King Brewery

Travel and beer.
CAMRA member West Suffolk and Borders.

beer.beer_description:
Our pale ale was christened by a local drinker, naming it after the iconic Battersea Park Pumphouse. Packed full of hops, our pale ale is a nod to overseas pale ale styles but keeps true to our British roots.
INGREDIENTS:
Maris Otter Pale Malt, Admiral, First Gold, Celeia and New Zealand Hallertau Hops.

Our pale ale was christened by a local drinker, naming it after the iconic Battersea Park Pumphouse. Packed full of hops, our pale ale is a nod to overseas pale ale styles but keeps true to our British roots.
INGREDIENTS:
Maris Otter Pale Malt, Admiral, First Gold, Celeia and New Zealand Hallertau Hops.

We brought out Junction Ale as our first anniversary ale. Being close to the UK‚Äôs busiest railway station I decided people needed another reason to go ‚ÄòUp the Junction‚Äô and Junction Ale was born. In style it is very different to Wandle and was brewed in tribute to a good friend of mine who often complains about ‚Äòtoo much flowery aromas in beers these days!‚Äô 

Junction is brewed as a traditional English bitter, using only English hop varieties, lots of crystal malt and a touch of roasted barley to give it an inviting auburn colour. Great with a steak pie or a roast dinner, Junction is a fine compliment to Wandle Ale, but loses none of its drinkability. Just treat it with a bit of respect, at 4.5% it is a little bit stronger than Wandle.

3.8% on draught
4.2% in bottles

Wandle Ale was the first beer that we brewed and I will never forget the taste of the first brew, produced on 26th November 2008. A beautiful golden sunshine colour with a clean, fresh sweetness cut through by a delicate lingering bitterness. The very thought of it makes me thirsty. 

The origin of the name ‚ÄòWandle‚Äô is from our local river ‚Äì a tributary to the Thames just minutes walk from the brewery. 

The river Wandle has helped to shape part of London‚Äôs industrial heritage, much like London‚Äôs brewing industry. So when we found out that trout had returned to the river after years of misuse at the same time as we had started brewing in Battersea, we took this to be a good omen and named our first beer Wandle.

user.bio: Love trying different beers. Always ready for a recommendation. Porters and Stouts are my favourites.

items.badge_description: Keep the party rolling all day long with your favorite low ABV session IPAs. That's 65 different beers with style of IPA - Session. Try 5 more for Level 14!
Take a whiff and enjoy that smooth, smoky aroma while you down the whole pint. That's 15 different Smoked beers. Try 5 more for Level 4!
Dating back to the 18th century, porters remain an extremely popular style to this day. That is 115 different beers with the style of Porter. Try 5 more Level 24!

beer.beer_description:
What better way to launch the first beer in our seasonal range that by brewing a porter; a style of beer synonymous with London. We looked no further for inspiration than Battersea‚Äôs most famous landmark (the Power Station) in naming our porter ‚Äì a strong rich beer needs a strong name. 

I personally love porters ‚Äì the richness and complexity from the different malts, the roasted coffee aroma and that feeling of pure satisfaction when supping one by a warm log fire. If you like porters I am sure that you won‚Äôt be disappointed by our modern take on this classic London beer style. If you have yet to try a porter....well what are you waiting for?.

Our pale ale was christened by a local drinker, naming it after the iconic Battersea Park Pumphouse. Packed full of hops, our pale ale is a nod to overseas pale ale styles but keeps true to our British roots.
INGREDIENTS:
Maris Otter Pale Malt, Admiral, First Gold, Celeia and New Zealand Hallertau Hops.

3.8% on draught
4.2% in bottles

Wandle Ale was the first beer that we brewed and I will never forget the taste of the first brew, produced on 26th November 2008. A beautiful golden sunshine colour with a clean, fresh sweetness cut through by a delicate lingering bitterness. The very thought of it makes me thirsty. 

The origin of the name ‚ÄòWandle‚Äô is from our local river ‚Äì a tributary to the Thames just minutes walk from the brewery. 

The river Wandle has helped to shape part of London‚Äôs industrial heritage, much like London‚Äôs brewing industry. So when we found out that trout had returned to the river after years of misuse at the same time as we had started brewing in Battersea, we took this to be a good omen and named our first beer Wandle.

We brought out Junction Ale as our first anniversary ale. Being close to the UK‚Äôs busiest railway station I decided people needed another reason to go ‚ÄòUp the Junction‚Äô and Junction Ale was born. In style it is very different to Wandle and was brewed in tribute to a good friend of mine who often complains about ‚Äòtoo much flowery aromas in beers these days!‚Äô 

Junction is brewed as a traditional English bitter, using only English hop varieties, lots of crystal malt and a touch of roasted barley to give it an inviting auburn colour. Great with a steak pie or a roast dinner, Junction is a fine compliment to Wandle Ale, but loses none of its drinkability. Just treat it with a bit of respect, at 4.5% it is a little bit stronger than Wandle.

What better way to launch the first beer in our seasonal range that by brewing a porter; a style of beer synonymous with London. We looked no further for inspiration than Battersea‚Äôs most famous landmark (the Power Station) in naming our porter ‚Äì a strong rich beer needs a strong name. 

I personally love porters ‚Äì the richness and complexity from the different malts, the roasted coffee aroma and that feeling of pure satisfaction when supping one by a warm log fire. If you like porters I am sure that you won‚Äôt be disappointed by our modern take on this classic London beer style. If you have yet to try a porter....well what are you waiting for?.

Cask ABV: 4.5%
Bottle & Keg ABV: 5.8%. 

Battersea Rye is a fusion of British hops with an American red rye recipe to produce a rich, spicy beer. Deep copper brown in colour, with a subtle rich fruit aroma, its flavours build to produce a bold spicy finish. Pale Malt, Malted Rye Crystal Malt, Northdown, Bramling X and WGV hops.

Sambrook‚Äôs Pale Ale is our inaugural craft keg product and is a beer born out of innovation. We have taken a German lagering technique known as Krausening and married this to a traditional British Pale Ale recipe. Dispensing the craft keg, unfiltered and unpasteurised, creates a fantastically flavoured craft keg beer with a light natural haze.  Maris Otter Pale Malt, Admiral, First Gold, Celeia and New Zealand Hallertau Hops.

Our session pale ale is a light, hop forward pale ale brewed with five different hop varieties. The US hop variety, Chinook provides the light bitterness while Mosaic, Summit, Simcoe and Ekuanot hops provide a citrus/peach aroma. Easy drinking, fresh and clean.

Brewed to 10.4% our Russian Imperial Stout is a special beer, complex yet smooth it has raisin, plum and dark fruit undertones with a rich malty finish. It is a multi-award winning beer with its highlight being winning supreme champion keg beer in the SIBA 2016 beer competition.
Hopped with Chinook, Citra and Simcoe.

This dark red ale is brewed using a blend of US hops which delivers vibrant citrus and pine aromas and grapefruit notes, balancing the roast malt, toffee and bready flavours in its dark malt profile. 
HOPS :- Cascade, Citra, Simcoe
Norwegian Red
Chocolate Stout

Named after The Evergreen State itself (Washington), this straw-coloured beer is a celebration of Yakima Valley hops, so delivers plenty of punchy citrus, pine resin and tropical fruit notes, culminating in a moreish, bitter, dry finish.
Previously brewed exclusively for the Draft House pub chain.
